messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The failing test `testParseInto_monthDay_feb29_tokyo_endOfYear()` is located in the `org.joda.time.format` package. Other failing tests cover classes from packages such as `org.joda.time.tz`, `org.joda.time.chrono`, and `org.joda.time.field`.

messages.name: get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class
messages.content: [".parseInto(org.joda.time.ReadWritableInstant, java.lang.String, int)", ".withLocale(java.util.Locale)", ".getLocale()", ".requireParser()", ".DateTimeFormatter(org.joda.time.format.DateTimePrinter, org.joda.time.format.DateTimeParser, java.util.Locale, boolean, org.joda.time.Chronology, org.joda.time.DateTimeZone, java.lang.Integer, int)", ".selectChronology(org.joda.time.Chronology)", ".getParser()", ".getPrinter()", ".DateTimeFormatter(org.joda.time.format.DateTimePrinter, org.joda.time.format.DateTimeParser)"]

messages.name: get_code_snippet
get_comments
messages.content:
" * Parses a datetime from the given text, at the given position, saving the * result into the fields of the given ReadWritableInstant. If the parse * succeeds, the return value is the new text position. Note that the parse * may succeed without fully reading the text and in this case those fields * that were read will be set. *

* Only those fields present in the string will be changed in the specified * instant. All other fields will remain unaltered. Thus if the string only * contains a year and a month, then the day and time will be retained from * the input instant. If this is not the behaviour you want, then reset the * fields before calling this method, or use {@link #parseDateTime(String)} * or {@link #parseMutableDateTime(String)}. *

* If it fails, the return value is negative, but the instant may still be * modified. To determine the position where the parse failed, apply the * one's complement operator (~) on the return value. *

* This parse method ignores the {@link #getDefaultYear() default year} and * parses using the year from the supplied instant based on the chronology * and time-zone of the supplied instant. *

* The parse will use the chronology of the instant. * * @param instant an instant that will be modified, not null * @param text the text to parse * @param position position to start parsing from * @return new position, negative value means parse failed - * apply complement operator (~) to get position of failure * @throws UnsupportedOperationException if parsing is not supported * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the instant is null * @throws IllegalArgumentException if any field is out of range "

The failing test `testParseInto_monthDay_feb29_tokyo_endOfYear()` is testing the `parseInto` method of the `DateTimeFormatter` class in the `org.joda.time.format` package.

Looking at the code snippet of the method, we can see that it takes a `ReadWritableInstant` object, a string `text`, and an integer `position` as inputs. It first checks if the `instant` object is null, and then retrieves the current instant's millis and chronology. It creates a `DateTimeParserBucket` object with the current instant's millis, chronology, locale, pivot year, and default year. It then calls the `parseInto` method of the parser with the bucket, text, and position parameters. After parsing, it sets the millis of the instant object to the computed value from the bucket. There are additional logic to handle parsed offset and zone.

Based on the error message, it seems that the parsing of the dayOfMonth field failed because the value 29 is out of range for the month of February. This is indicated by the `IllegalFieldValueException: Cannot parse "2 29": Value 29 for dayOfMonth must be in the range [1,28]` message.

To fix the issue, the `parseInto` method should handle the case where the dayOfMonth value is out of range for the given month. It can either throw an exception or handle it gracefully by setting the dayOfMonth to the maximum valid value for the given month.

To prevent such issues in the future, it may be beneficial to add proper validation checks for the input text and handle invalid values in an appropriate manner.

Suggested fix:
- Class: `org.joda.time.format.DateTimeParserBucket`
  - Method: `parseInto(org.joda.time.MutableDateTime, java.lang.String, int)`
- Class: `org.joda.time.format.DateTimeFormatter`
  - Method: `parseInto(org.joda.time.ReadWritableInstant, java.lang.String, int)`

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).

" * Parses a datetime from the given text, at the given position, saving the * result into the fields of the given ReadWritableInstant. If the parse * succeeds, the return value is the new text position. Note that the parse * may succeed without fully reading the text and in this case those fields * that were read will be set. *

Thus if the string only * contains a year and a month, then the day and time will be retained from * the input instant. If this is not the behaviour you want, then reset the * fields before calling this method, or use {@link #parseDateTime(String)} * or {@link #parseMutableDateTime(String)}. *

* This parse method ignores the {@link #getDefaultYear() default year} and * parses using the year from the supplied instant based on the chronology * and time-zone of the supplied instant. *

* The parse will use the chronology of the instant. * * @param instant an instant that will be modified, not null * @param text the text to parse * @param position position to start parsing from * @return new position, negative value means parse failed - * apply complement operator (~) to get position of failure * @throws UnsupportedOperationException if parsing is not supported * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the instant is null * @throws IllegalArgumentException if any field is out of range "

m11.content:
The failing test `testParseInto_monthDay_feb29_tokyo_endOfYear()` is testing the `parseInto` method of the `DateTimeFormatter` class in the `org.joda.time.format` package.

Looking at the code snippet of the method, we can see that it takes a `ReadWritableInstant` object, a string `text`, and an integer `position` as inputs. It first checks if the `instant` object is null, and then retrieves the current instant's millis and chronology. It creates a `DateTimeParserBucket` object with the current instant's millis, chronology, locale, pivot year, and default year. It then calls the `parseInto` method of the parser with the bucket, text, and position parameters. After parsing, it sets the millis of the instant object to the computed value from the bucket. There are additional logic to handle parsed offset and zone.

Based on the error message, it seems that the parsing of the dayOfMonth field failed because the value 29 is out of range for the month of February. This is indicated by the `IllegalFieldValueException: Cannot parse "2 29": Value 29 for dayOfMonth must be in the range [1,28]` message.

To fix the issue, the `parseInto` method should handle the case where the dayOfMonth value is out of range for the given month. It can either throw an exception or handle it gracefully by setting the dayOfMonth to the maximum valid value for the given month.

To prevent such issues in the future, it may be beneficial to add proper validation checks for the input text and handle invalid values in an appropriate manner.

Suggested fix:
- Class: `org.joda.time.format.DateTimeParserBucket`
  - Method: `parseInto(org.joda.time.MutableDateTime, java.lang.String, int)`
- Class: `org.joda.time.format.DateTimeFormatter`
  - Method: `parseInto(org.joda.time.ReadWritableInstant, java.lang.String, int)`
